name: Parallel Circuits
what: This subtopic covers the behaviour of current and potential difference in parallel circuits, calculation of equivalent resistance, and comparison with series circuits.
why: Parallel circuits power our homes because each device receives full voltage and operates independently. Understanding parallel behaviour is essential for household wiring and electronic design.

items.title: I can identify a parallel circuit as one with branches where current splits at junctions
items.what: In a parallel circuit, current has multiple paths. At each junction, current splits into branches and recombines when branches rejoin. Total current equals the sum of branch currents.
items.why: Recognising parallel connections is essential because they behave very differently from series connections in terms of current distribution and equivalent resistance.
items.example: In a circuit with two parallel resistors, 3 A from the battery might split into 2 A through the first resistor and 1 A through the second, then recombine to return 3 A to the battery.

items.title: I can explain that potential difference is the same across all branches in parallel
items.what: Each branch of a parallel circuit connects directly to the power supply terminals, so every branch experiences the same potential difference regardless of its resistance.
items.why: This property explains why household appliances work correctly when plugged into any outlet - they all receive the same 230 V supply.
items.example: A 12 V battery connected to three parallel resistors provides 12 V across each resistor. A voltmeter placed across any of the three resistors will read 12 V.

items.title: I can calculate equivalent resistance in parallel using 1/R_eq = 1/R‚ÇÅ + 1/R‚ÇÇ + ... + 1/R‚Çô
items.what: The reciprocal of equivalent resistance equals the sum of reciprocals of individual resistances. For two resistors, this simplifies to R_eq = (R‚ÇÅ √ó R‚ÇÇ)/(R‚ÇÅ + R‚ÇÇ).
items.why: Parallel equivalent resistance is always less than the smallest individual resistance because adding paths makes it easier for current to flow.
items.example: Two 10 Œ© resistors in parallel: R_eq = (10 √ó 10)/(10 + 10) = 100/20 = 5 Œ©. Adding a parallel path halves the equivalent resistance.

items.title: I can calculate current through each branch of a parallel circuit
items.what: Since each branch has the same potential difference, use I = V/R for each branch separately. The branch with lowest resistance carries the most current.
items.why: Knowing individual branch currents is essential for selecting appropriate wire sizes and ensuring components are not overloaded.
items.example: With 12 V across parallel branches of 6 Œ© and 4 Œ©: I‚ÇÅ = 12/6 = 2 A and I‚ÇÇ = 12/4 = 3 A. Total current from battery is 2 + 3 = 5 A.

items.title: I can use I-V graphs to predict equivalent resistance of components in parallel
items.what: For parallel components, add the currents at each voltage value to construct the combined I-V graph. The steeper gradient indicates lower equivalent resistance.
items.why: Graphical methods handle non-ohmic components in parallel, allowing analysis of real circuits with varying resistance.
items.example: At 6 V, component A draws 2 A and component B draws 1 A. In parallel at 6 V, total current is 3 A. Equivalent resistance is 6/3 = 2 Œ©.

items.title: I can analyse circuits containing both series and parallel sections
items.what: Complex circuits are simplified by first finding the equivalent resistance of parallel sections, then treating the result as a single resistor in series with other components.
items.why: Most real circuits combine series and parallel elements, so this systematic approach is essential for analysing practical circuits.
items.example: A circuit has a 4 Œ© resistor in series with two 8 Œ© resistors in parallel. The parallel section has R_eq = 4 Œ©. Total resistance is 4 + 4 = 8 Œ©.
